source.name: City of Charlotte Solid Waste Services
source.notes: Based on official City of Charlotte collection guidelines. Bi-weekly recycling on Green/Orange week schedule. Only plastic bottles and jugs WITH necks accepted (no tubs/clamshells).

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Charlotte only accepts plastic bottles and jugs with necks
No tubs, cups, clamshells, or trays
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic tubs or containers without necks
Don't include bottles with liquid still inside

materials.name: Plastic jugs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Must have a neck to qualify for Charlotte recycling
Jugs are accepted; tubs are not
commonMistakes: Don't flatten jugs; leave them as-is with cap on

materials.name: Plastic tubs and containers
instructions: Place in trash
Charlotte does NOT accept plastic tubs, cups, or clamshells
notes: Only bottles and jugs with necks are recyclable in Charlotte
This is a common source of confusion
commonMistakes: Don't put yogurt tubs in recycling
Don't put clamshells or deli containers in recycling

materials.name: Cardboard / small boxes
instructions: Cut or tear into small pieces that fit in the cart
Remove packing materials
Place in green recycling cart with lid closed
notes: All cardboard must be cut or torn into small pieces
Items must fit with the lid closed
commonMistakes: Don't leave large uncut cardboard; it will not be collected
Remove all packing materials like styrofoam and bubble wrap

materials.name: Large uncut cardboard
instructions: Cut or tear into small pieces first, then recycle
If too large to fit in cart with lid closed, it will NOT be collected
Break down before placing in recycling cart
notes: Charlotte requires all cardboard to fit inside the cart with the lid closed
Uncut large cardboard left beside the cart will be rejected
commonMistakes: Don't leave large cardboard next to the cart; it won't be picked up
Always cut or tear into manageable pieces

materials.name: Paper and magazines
instructions: Place loose in green recycling cart
No need to remove staples or window envelopes
notes: Must be dry and clean
Do not bag paper in plastic bags
commonMistakes: Don't include shredded paper; it clogs machinery
Don't include wet or food-soiled paper

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in trash
Charlotte does NOT accept shredded paper in recycling
notes: Shredded paper clogs recycling equipment and is too small to sort
Consider composting at home if possible
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in the green recycling cart
Don't bag shredded paper and put it in recycling

materials.name: Milk / juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Cartons are accepted in Charlotte curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include cartons with liquid still inside

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Lids can stay on
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Charlotte accepts glass in curbside recycling
Lids do not need to be removed
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and trash it
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics

materials.name: Empty metal cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Labels can stay on
Includes aluminum and steel/tin cans
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue
Don't crush cans; leave them as-is

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up into a ball at least 2 inches wide
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food
Small pieces get lost; ball them together

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Non-empty aerosol cans are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if can still has pressure or product

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT put in green recycling cart
Take to Harris Teeter, Walmart, or Target for store drop-off
Otherwise place in trash
notes: Plastic bags jam Charlotte's recycling machinery
Most grocery stores in Charlotte accept bags for recycling
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Never put film plastic in the green cart

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: Place in trash
Not accepted in Charlotte recycling
notes: Styrofoam is not recyclable curbside in Charlotte
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Food waste
instructions: Place in trash
Charlotte does not offer curbside composting
notes: No curbside composting program available in Charlotte
Consider backyard composting for food scraps
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in brown paper yard waste bags or an unlidded container marked 'yard waste'
Branches must be cut to 4 feet or shorter and bundled
Set out on your regular collection day
notes: Charlotte collects yard waste separately from trash
Do not use plastic bags for yard waste
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Paper plates and napkins
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable when soiled with food
notes: Food-contaminated paper products are not accepted in Charlotte recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Takeout containers
instructions: Place in trash
Not accepted in Charlotte recycling
notes: Takeout containers are typically food-soiled and made of non-recyclable materials in Charlotte
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart even if rinsed

materials.name: Plastic utensils and cups
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable in Charlotte
notes: Plastic utensils and cups are not accepted in Charlotte recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic utensils in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Plastic food trays
instructions: Place in trash
Charlotte does not accept plastic food trays
notes: Only bottles and jugs with necks are recyclable plastic in Charlotte
commonMistakes: Don't put food trays in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Hoses and cords
instructions: Place in trash
Do NOT put in green recycling cart
notes: Hoses and cords tangle in recycling machinery and shut down the sorting facility
commonMistakes: Never put hoses, cords, or cables in recycling

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not put in trash or recycling
Take to Mecklenburg County Household Hazardous Waste collection
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries cause fires in recycling trucks
Mecklenburg County holds periodic hazardous waste collection events
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in trash or recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to Mecklenburg County recycling centers
Best Buy accepts many electronics for free
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: North Carolina law prohibits putting electronics in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or recycling cart

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to Mecklenburg County Household Hazardous Waste collection
Latex paint: can also dry out with kitty litter and trash the solid
Oil-based paint: must go to hazardous waste
notes: Mecklenburg County holds HHW events for Charlotte residents
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to Mecklenburg County recycling center
AutoZone and O'Reilly in Charlotte also accept used oil
notes: Most auto parts stores accept oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or into storm drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to Charlotte-area drug take-back locations
CVS and Walgreens in Charlotte participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal in bag, and trash
notes: Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police holds periodic drug take-back events
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications down the toilet

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local Charlotte thrift stores
Textile recycling bins at various Charlotte locations
Even worn-out textiles are accepted in textile bins
notes: Charlotte has many donation and textile recycling options
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to Mecklenburg County HHW or Home Depot/Lowe's
LED bulbs: e-waste recycling
Incandescent: wrap and place in trash
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury and require special handling
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in trash

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition
If damaged, place in green recycling cart
Remove hardcover bindings with glossy laminate (trash those)
notes: Charlotte-Mecklenburg Library accepts book donations
Donating is always preferred over recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in the trash

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in trash
Plastic-lined paper cups are not recyclable in Charlotte
notes: The plastic lining prevents recycling
Plastic lids: also trash in Charlotte
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Place in trash
Thermal paper contains BPA and contaminates recycling
notes: Thermal receipts are not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put receipts in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Candy wrappers
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized plastic film is not recyclable
notes: Wrappers look metallic but are multi-layer plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Chip bags / snack bags
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized film; not recyclable in Charlotte
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: If heavily soiled with grease: place in trash
If clean (top half): tear off clean portion and recycle that part
notes: Food-soiled cardboard is not accepted in Charlotte recycling
Charlotte has no curbside composting to handle greasy paper
commonMistakes: Don't put grease-soaked cardboard in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Place in trash
Or take plastic film to store drop-off bins
notes: Plastic film is not accepted in Charlotte curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Cereal box / paperboard
instructions: Flatten
Remove plastic liner bag (trash it)
Tear or cut to fit in green recycling cart
notes: Thin paperboard is recyclable in Charlotte
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the plastic liner

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Place in trash
Food-soiled paper is not recyclable in Charlotte
notes: Charlotte has no curbside composting for food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to Mecklenburg County recycling center
Never pour down the drain
notes: Grease causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to Mecklenburg County Household Hazardous Waste facility
Never put in trash or recycling
notes: Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture or put in trash

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in puncture-resistant sharps container
Take to Mecklenburg County HHW or check with your pharmacy
notes: Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in trash

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup through Charlotte 311 or CLTplus app
Or take to a Mecklenburg County full-service recycling center
notes: Charlotte offers bulk item pickup by request
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule bulk pickup through Charlotte 311 or CLTplus app
Place at curb on scheduled day
notes: Charlotte offers scheduled bulk pickups
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or Mecklenburg County recycling center
Do NOT put in green recycling cart
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Never put cables in curbside recycling

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe data first
Trade in at carrier stores or Apple/Samsung
Take to Best Buy for free recycling
notes: NC law prohibits electronics in trash
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: Place in trash
Charlotte does not have curbside composting
notes: Consider backyard composting if possible
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in trash
No curbside composting in Charlotte
notes: Consider backyard composting
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in recycling

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Charlotte does not have curbside composting
commonMistakes: Don't put meat or bones in recycling

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Pour expired liquids down drain
Solid dairy products in trash
Rinse and recycle containers separately
notes: No curbside composting in Charlotte
commonMistakes: Rinse the container before recycling it

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: Place in trash
Charlotte does not have curbside composting
notes: Consider backyard composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Pet waste contains harmful bacteria
commonMistakes: Never compost pet waste
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable due to wax/silicone coating
notes: Charlotte does not have curbside composting for these items
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully and place in trash
Label bag as 'BROKEN GLASS' if applicable
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put mirrors in recycling

materials.name: Ceramics and pottery
instructions: Place in trash
Ceramics are not recyclable
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put ceramics or broken dishes in recycling

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot
Manufacturers offer mail-back programs
notes: Some stores give credit for cartridge returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to Mecklenburg County HHW or Home Depot/Lowe's
Handle carefully to avoid breakage
notes: Contains mercury; requires special handling
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling
Don't break them

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to tire retailer or Mecklenburg County recycling center
notes: Most shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in trash
notes: Mixed plastic; not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics
instructions: Most containers go in trash
Check brand take-back programs for recycling options
notes: Small items fall through sorting screens at recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Nail polish is hazardous; take to HHW if possible

materials.name: Egg cartons
instructions: Paper/cardboard egg cartons: place in green recycling cart
Styrofoam egg cartons: place in trash
notes: Only paper-based cartons are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle styrofoam egg cartons

materials.name: Metal lids and caps
instructions: Leave lids on glass jars
Loose metal lids: place inside a metal can and crimp the top to contain them
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Small loose lids can fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't put loose small caps in recycling; contain them in a can

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in green recycling cart
notes: Clean paper bags are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle paper bags soiled with food

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Most wrapping paper goes in trash due to glitter, foil, or plastic lamination
Plain paper wrapping (no glitter/foil): can be recycled
notes: Do the scrunch test: if it stays scrunched it may be recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't assume all wrapping paper is recyclable

materials.name: Cleaning products / chemicals
instructions: Take to Mecklenburg County Household Hazardous Waste collection
Empty containers that held non-hazardous cleaners: rinse and recycle if #1 or #2 plastic bottle
notes: Never mix chemicals together
commonMistakes: Don't pour chemicals down drains
Don't put partially full containers in trash

recycle: Cardboard and small boxes (cut or torn into small pieces)
Plastic bottles and jugs with necks
Glass bottles and jars (lids can stay on)
trash: Plastic tubs, cups, clamshells, and trays

recycle: Large uncut cardboard that won't fit in cart
Plastic bags, food trays, cups, and plasticware

tips: Recycling is collected bi-weekly on your Green or Orange week schedule
Check your schedule with the My Charlotte Lookup tool
Cart must be within 6 feet of the curb by 6 AM on collection day
All items must fit in the cart with the lid closed
Only plastic bottles and jugs WITH necks are recyclable (no tubs, cups, or clamshells)
Cut or tear all cardboard into small pieces before recycling
Charlotte has NO curbside composting program

locations.name: Mecklenburg County HHW Facility
locations.notes: Household Hazardous Waste collection for Mecklenburg County residents.
